docs.snippet: Temptations from heaven are as perilous as those from hell, a clever peasant discovers in ''Tiene la Muerte Atada'' (''They've Got Death Bound Up''). This is the wittiest, most lyrical and colorful free summer show the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater...
docs.lead_paragraph: Temptations from heaven are as perilous as those from hell, a clever peasant discovers in ''Tiene la Muerte Atada'' (''They've Got Death Bound Up''). This is the wittiest, most lyrical and colorful free summer show the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater and Pregones Theater have ever presented in their annual series. This year it is running in parks in all five boroughs of the city and at several New Jersey sites, through Aug. 29. This operatic comedy has a distinctly Uruguayan spirit. The playwright, Hugo Bardallo, spices a medieval folk tale with dialogue so funny and subtle that he packs into one hour more humor and irony than would seem possible. He is an honored master of murga, a Mardi Gras theatrical genre involving commedia dell'arte, song, dance, music based on Latin American and African rhythms thrummed out on drums and cymbals, and high-pitched choruses that seem to be sung, with hilarious effect, directly through the nose.
docs.abstract: D J R Bruckner reviews Puerto Rican Traveling Theater and Pregones Theater performance of Hugo Bardallo's play Tiene la Muerte Atada (They've Got Death Bound Up), with music by Pablo Zinger; Nelson Landrieu directs; photos (M)

headline.main: Death Gambles and the Neighborhood Loses

docs.snippet: Two agencies said yesterday that they had expanded.    EPB Communications in New York has acquired Pagano Schenck & Kay, a Boston-based advertising agency with billings last year estimated at $30 million from accounts like A. T. Cross Pens, Cambridge...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two agencies said yesterday that they had expanded. EPB Communications in New York has acquired Pagano Schenck & Kay, a Boston-based advertising agency with billings last year estimated at $30 million from accounts like A. T. Cross Pens, Cambridge Soundworks and Linx Communications. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.
docs.abstract: EPB Communications has acquired Pagano Schenck & Kay; financial terms undisclosed; Lowe & Partners Worldwide expands its agency network to Uruguay by entering into partnership with Ginkgo Inc, full-service advertising agency in Montevideo (S)

docs.snippet: Geraldo Ferregetti was overjoyed when his company, a prominent fruit producer, signed a contract last week to supply 100 tons of papayas each month to Carrefour S.A., Brazil's largest retailer.    ''Selling to Carrefour is like securing our future,''...
docs.lead_paragraph: Geraldo Ferregetti was overjoyed when his company, a prominent fruit producer, signed a contract last week to supply 100 tons of papayas each month to Carrefour S.A., Brazil's largest retailer. ''Selling to Carrefour is like securing our future,'' Mr. Ferregetti, the produce director at Caliman Agricola, said in a telephone interview from the company's headquarters in the southeastern state of Espirito Santo. Mr. Ferregetti said the next step was to use Carrefour's global reach to sell papayas in Europe, Asia and Latin America.
docs.abstract: Carrefour SA's agreement to buy rival Promodes SA is expected to make Carrefour's presence in Latin America stronger; Carrefour has been on acquisition binge over last few years (M)

headline.main: A Strong Latin Presence Is About to Get Stronger

docs.snippet: The United States Open extracted its usual emotional baggage yesterday from the combatants who took to the windblown hardcourts at the National Tennis Center: frayed nerves, gray hair, stage fright; the mean streak that flares when a defending Grand...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Open extracted its usual emotional baggage yesterday from the combatants who took to the windblown hardcourts at the National Tennis Center: frayed nerves, gray hair, stage fright; the mean streak that flares when a defending Grand Slam champion finds a friend blocking her passage to the second round; the adrenaline that flows when a two-time defending champion finds himself in danger of becoming the first incumbent ever to fail in the first round. But Patrick Rafter, the two-time defending champion, suffered longest, hardest and last. Worse, he suffered in vain. It was getting on toward midnight at Arthur Ashe Stadium when Rafter, who came into this daunting Slam hobbled by shoulder tendinitis, gave up the ghost in his opener against Cedric Pioline just after surrendering his serve in the first game of the fifth set.
docs.abstract: Patrick Rafter, defending US Open champion, retires from his first-round match with Cedric Pioline because of sore shoulder; photo (M)

headline.main: On Day 2, a Bad Case of Tennis Withdrawal

docs.snippet: Officials said today that at least 74 people were killed in the crash of a Boeing 737 belonging to the Argentine airline LAPA on Tuesday, and workers continued to pull bodies from the wreckage.    At least 64 of the 100 people on the plane were...
docs.lead_paragraph: Officials said today that at least 74 people were killed in the crash of a Boeing 737 belonging to the Argentine airline LAPA on Tuesday, and workers continued to pull bodies from the wreckage. At least 64 of the 100 people on the plane were killed, said a Government spokeswoman, Olga Riugord. And a morgue official told the news agency Reuters that at least 10 people on the ground had been killed.
docs.abstract: Officials say at least 64 of 100 people on LAPA jet and at least 10 on ground were killed when plane crashed on takeoff from Buenos Aires; workers continue to pull bodies from wreckage (M)

headline.main: Death Toll in Argentine Jet Crash Is Put at 74

docs.snippet: This week in the Berkshire hills, 191 people gathered to play baseball, do yoga and tai chi, sing campfire songs, dance, listen to lectures and watch movies. It would have been an unremarkable summer retreat, except that every word spoken was in a...
docs.lead_paragraph: This week in the Berkshire hills, 191 people gathered to play baseball, do yoga and tai chi, sing campfire songs, dance, listen to lectures and watch movies. It would have been an unremarkable summer retreat, except that every word spoken was in a language many people imagine to be if not vanished, then just ahead of the California condor on the endangered species list. Yiddish-vokh, or Yiddish week, is an annual retreat organized by Yugntruf (yugntruf@yugntruf.org), a group dedicated to preserving the language. Although many of the campers were over 60, there were also three dozen children and teen-agers, virtually all raised in Yiddish-speaking households. About a dozen of the campers were not Jewish, and the vast majority of Jews were not religious. People traveled from Uruguay, Denmark and England -- and Japan, which has in recent years sent a large contingent. Interest in Yiddish there is mainly due to the country's World War II history.
docs.abstract: Editorial Notebook by Tina Rosenberg on efforts of Dr Mordkhe Schaechter and others to preserve Yiddish language; notes that while Yiddish language is used daily by 700,000 people worldwide, mostly ultra-Orthodox Hasidim, small group of secular Jews is trying to preserve Yiddish in non-religious world, and to maintain language's literary treasures; describes Yiddish-vokh, or Yiddish week, annual retreat in Berkshires

headline.main: Editorial Notebook; Living an American Life -- in Yiddish

docs.abstract: Gonzalo Rodriguez. rookie driver, is killed in practice session for Shell 300 at Laguna Seca Raceway, Monterey, Calif (S)

docs.snippet: On Lap 30 of the 70th Italian Grand Prix at Monza yesterday, Mika Hakkinen threw his racing glove to the ground, stepped into the trees off the side of the track, dropped to his knees and buried his face in his hands. The Italian fans, most of whom...
docs.lead_paragraph: On Lap 30 of the 70th Italian Grand Prix at Monza yesterday, Mika Hakkinen threw his racing glove to the ground, stepped into the trees off the side of the track, dropped to his knees and buried his face in his hands. The Italian fans, most of whom were dressed in Ferrari-red T-shirts, rose to their feet, cheered and honked their compressed air horns in delight.

headline.main: Hakkinen's Error Is Boon for Irvine

docs.snippet: Brazil dispatched two high-ranking trade negotiators, Jose Alfredo Graca Lima and Jose Botafogo Goncalves, to Buenos Aires to meet with Argentine counterparts to discuss measures restricting imports of Brazilian shoes, textiles and steel and a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil dispatched two high-ranking trade negotiators, Jose Alfredo Graca Lima and Jose Botafogo Goncalves, to Buenos Aires to meet with Argentine counterparts to discuss measures restricting imports of Brazilian shoes, textiles and steel and a possible limit on paper shipments. Brazil's currency devaluation earlier this year has made its exports cheaper and raised tensions with neighboring Argentina, threatening the unity of the Mercosur trade bloc, which also includes Paraguay and Uruguay. Simon Romero (NYT)
docs.abstract: Brazil dispatches high-ranking trade negotiators Jose Alfredo Garcia Lima and Jose Botafogo Goncalves to Buenos Aires to meet with Argentine counterparts to discuss measures restricting imports of Brazilian shoes, textiles and steel and possible limit on paper shipments; Brazil's currency devaluation earlier this year has made its exports cheaper and raised tensions with neighboring Argentina, threatening unity of Mercosur trade bloc, which also includes Paraguay and Uruguay (S)

docs.snippet: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER     The long-awaited meeting of the officials who determine Major League Soccer's fortunes will take place next Monday and Tuesday in Denver. The league's competition committee, headed by Clark Hunt of Columbus, will meet on...
docs.lead_paragraph: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER The long-awaited meeting of the officials who determine Major League Soccer's fortunes will take place next Monday and Tuesday in Denver. The league's competition committee, headed by Clark Hunt of Columbus, will meet on Monday and make its recommendations at Tuesday's meeting of the board of governors, which is headed by Stuart Subotnick of the MetroStars. The top items on the agenda are the shootout and the mechanism for allocating players to teams, with the two-referee system perhaps the third item of priority. The league is seriously considering abandoning the shootout, its method of deciding tie games. It has been disliked by coaches and players all along, but some prefer it over penalty kicks.
